newsitem.title: USA: NYCE cotton futures close firmer with soybeans.
newsitem.headline: NYCE cotton futures close firmer with soybeans.

text.p: NYCE cotton futures closed slightly higher after a rally in soybean futures sparked buying interest in cotton, market analysts said.
Local and trade buying lifted prices amid thin volume estimated at 7,000 lots compared to Wednesday's official 15,205 lots.
Most-active May settled up 0.33 at 74.25 cents per lb, having ranged from 74.57 to 73.95. The back months closed 0.05 to 0.55 cent firmer.
Resistance was pegged at 75.50 cents in May.
Merrill Lynch analyst Judith Ganes said several fundamental factors provided underpinning to today's market.
Talk that planted area in China could fall by as much as 25 percent, coupled with worries that floods in the Southeast will cut U.S. area, supported new crop prices.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's weekly export and sales report was mostly neutral for prices but may have prevented losses in the old crop, Ganes said.
While the USDA put new sales at only 79,800 480-lb bales for the week ended March 13, the number was higher than industry sources had anticipated. Shipments were strong at 194,000 bales.
Near-term pressure could come from certificated stocks, which rose to 200,192 bales as of March 19 from 199,568 bales the previous day, analysts said.
Open interest in May fell 521 lots to 30,541 lots.
